commentBody: Neat puzzle, but this is not a Tuesday.

I like that both OUTS and bUTS fit for 31A (fortunately 3D made it clear which one it was.)

Fun theme, once I could convince myself that it had nothing to do with LIFE OF Pi--17A was the only one I came close to figuring out from crosses prior to the "oh THAT'S the theme!" lightbulb.

‚ôØ   This is a a sharp (if it shows up properly in the published comment), with two vertical strokes.

#   This is a a pound sign, hash, or number sign, with two horizontal strokes.

What part of a club is a TOMATO?

Nice Wednesday puzzle.

This is the first time I finished a puzzle with no hints! I just started really playing these crosswords about a month ago so I‚Äôm ATAD proud of myself. :) This was a fun puzzle to play. 

I kept thinking ‚Äúorcas‚Äù would be involved with ramming boats and scaring people in 17A, so that was the last part I could get.

This felt hard for a Wednesday, but at 13:40, my solve time was indeed below my Wednesday average. Not sure what was meant by ERSE, but DIANa/aRSE seemed to make sense until I remembered her first name was really DIANE

I completed the puzzle and received my on-screen "Congratulations", yet, the timer continues to tick away, and the puzzle is locked, not permitting letter deletions, etc. (indicating that is has, indeed, been completed).

Fun theme
Well clued
What's not to like?
**************

I needed the comments below to understand that the club a tomato is part of is a CLUB sandwich. This - and many previous puzzles - made me realize the American terminology for sandwiches is much more standardized than the Polish one. Over here sandwiches, even though they are popular breakfast and lunch items, do not have commonly or even regionally known types or names - no heros, hoagies, BLTs, lobster rolls, Italian or club sandwiches for us Polish people. 

Sure, each bar or restaurant usually names their sandwiches, but these names are idiosyncratic. The standard way to describe a sandwich in universally recognized term is to just list its ingredients. 

Also, when we visited the US, I was amazed by how much meat you stuff into your sandwiches. Slice upon slice upon slice upon slice. That was so weird compared to European standards! And the weird, soft, sweet bread...
Barbara Lin, I loved this puzzle and your notes. The only difference between you and me is that I know I‚Äôm funnier than my family thinks I am.
Great crossword with fun theme, but personally I think it could have been better with a revealer. Something like REVERSEORDER or like that. Could just be me though.
LIONS OF PRIDE!!!! Yasss queen xo
Great puzzle! Fun theme, well executed. Interesting entries and good cluing. Much appreciated.

Nice puzzle with great choices for the themers.  LIFE OF JAWS and FORTUNES OF CHANGE were favorites, but all were excellent.  

I think this was the first time I wrote in OPI without a second thought.  It's finally cemented in my brain.

I was amused by the theme, nice puzzle.

I did get quite stuck on some of the crossings (OPI / GILA, DIANE / ERSE, ODAMAE / TET), but got there eventually.

Laboured‚Ä¶felt like more hard work than it ought to have been. 

Crosses got a bit obscure ERSE and spelling of NEWB were a little painful.  In jolly old England we say
IF NEEDs BE.  

Liked noodling through the theme would have liked the crosses to be a little more consistent to help , but can‚Äôt have everything :)

Had to take a break during this puzzle to feed the boss -- cattus interruptus, you might say.

Sorry.
I enjoyed figuring out the theme entries..very fun. Had a lot of trouble with the northwest at first, but persevered and got it!

Fun puzzle and an enjoyable solve. Had to go through the down answers before I caught on but then the theme answers came together pretty smoothly. Ended up right at my Wednesday average. 

Interesting puzzle find today that I'll put in a reply. 

..

Gliding along‚Ä¶feeling quite chuffed‚Ä¶

(‚ÄúI‚Äôm really good at this‚Ä¶lah-dee-dah‚Ä¶ üé∂‚Ä¶)

Then, bam. 
Stuck in the mud of
FUTs
ANTs
COA‚Ä¶s??

For sooo long.

Oh, FUTZ!

But fun puzzle with a clever theme!
Thoroughly enjoyed!

Until‚Ä¶you know‚Ä¶

NEEDBE (insert high dudgeon about here).

Guess what word we missed.

Fun solve other than the aforementioned. And, if we only paid attention to the grid.... sigh

Thank you Barbara

I'm definitely back in the groove with this fun puzzle! Sailed through it, not with a blistering time but under my average.

Once I got the theme, I had a lot of fun trying to guess the theme answers without looking at the clues. Not always successfully, but it was enjoyable. 

I'll have to hint down the puzzle with a similar theme.

‚ÄúHah!‚Äù is how I reacted to LIFE OF JAWS, from the sweet ping at seeing the scheme, to the funny clue, to knowing what the other theme answers would do and knowing there would be fun ahead in trying to guess them with as few crosses as possible.  Knowing that each would be a riddle to crack rather than a mindless slapdown.

I did love that huge piggy bank, the regal feel of LIONS OF PRIDE, and the sheer silliness of ARMS OF COAT.

Not to mention answers that added beauty to the solve: ARROYOS, NONE BUT, BEHAVIORAL and KINETIC ART.  Add in three palindromes (ERE, TET, ONO) and a trio of longer semordnilaps (A TAD, DEFER, and G ILA).  Sweetness all around in the box.

I‚Äôm still remembering the stellar wordplay of Barbara‚Äôs last solo puzzle (8/2/23), where the theme answers were, get this, syllable palindromes!  For example, KAZOO BAZOOKA, which forward is KA ZOO BA ZOO KA, and backward is KA ZOO BA ZOO KA.  Another answer was TIC TAC TOE TACTIC.

Wordplay like that and like in today‚Äôs puzzle tickles me top to bottom.  More, please, Barbara, and thank you for today's stellar outing!
Way slower (33% slower) than the average today. Which if nothing else, makes for a good challenge and a lot of false starts. This was definitely not a Monday puzzle!
Lingered too long over a nice CUP of soup.

OH COOL

I loved all the theme entries, each one brought a smile as I figured it out, can‚Äôt ask for much more than that.  Also just about right for a Wednesday.

Looking forward to your next one,  Barbara.

Great puzzle. I loved the LIFEOFJAWS clue. I went through the puzzle twice though and could not find the error keeping me from completion. I resorted to checking the column and quickly found that I was missing a zed in FUTs and ANTs. Funny the things your brain allows.

Fun theme! Nicely done, Barbara. 

And since I love a good MUSICAL (and the crossing with SHARPS), here‚Äôs my contribution to the theme.

76 trombones

PLENTY OF HORN


‚ôØ ‚ôØ ‚ôØ
Maybe it has been pointed out but the shark in Jaws had no name. It certainly wasn't "Jaws." The crew referred to him as "Bruce".
Might be my favorite Wednesday of all time. Clever, just enough misdirection, and 17A clue is perfect. Well done!
could someone please explain 42A (SLAY) to me? maybe i‚Äôm thinking too hard about it‚Ä¶

That cost me five minutes. Shoulda spotted that more quickly.

Trickiest Clue goes to:   47D Part of a club
I had it filled in from crosses, and thought, "What??"  Doh!

Really nice puzzle for the day; thank you, Ms. Lin!
Fun puzzle! Thanks to Ms Lin and the editors :)
A bit tougher than I expected for a Wednesday. Really enjoyable! Thank you for a great puzzle!

Please tell me I'm not the only one who thought of Tom Tom Club at 47D. Elsa Einstein would solve to LOVE OF GENIUS. LOLed when I got the TOMATO. FUTZ made me smile, as that was my mom's description of what dad was doing in his workshop.

I didn't get the ### clue, and unfortunately had MOTOR instead of ROTOR at the cross. I kept looking at it wonder what SHAMPS had to do with octothorpes, or parsing it weirdly. S-HAMPS? SHAM P's? Forehead slapper in the end.

I'm in with the in crowd...

So don't defer
To mindless rot
Do not defer
Then sob, "I lost"

Odamae can you see
A newb, she needbe
A new armsofcoat
Changeofseed - that's for me

Imagine my surprise when today's theme ECHOed Will Nediger's and my TURNS OF PHRASE puzzle of Sunday, 1/23/22 in the NYT.  But Barbara's themers are all different and I'm sure she had no idea of the similarity because absolutely no one can see every puzzle or remember every puzzle that has ever come down the pike.  

Perhaps the NYT should have remembered though?

Anyway, I found it a very enjoyable puzzle -- and while "jaws of life" is not a phrase I'm familiar with, I did love the playful way it was clued.   I thought the best clue/answer combo was LOVE OF LABORS.  And I sort of imagine that even after combining this puzzle with my previous Sunday puzzle, the potential list of reversible "of" phrases has yet to be exhausted.  Will we be seeing a third such puzzle in the not-too-distant future?

Another tricky one for me. TIL FUTZ, not a word/expression I‚Äôve heard before, crossing a film I haven‚Äôt seen was tough. I threw in the Z as a last resort and was v surprised to get the happy music. 

Needed the Wordplay column to understand the theme, which of course was obvious once you knew. Which I didn‚Äôt. *head slap*.

Ingenious!  My favorite was LIFE OF JAWS.  Great clue! I just have one question:  How is a TOMATO part of a club?


Do emus eat tomatoes?

Finished in 41:45, after turning on auto check. Sometimes you get off on the wrong foot and end up with a bunch of incorrect answers

Loved this theme.
I'm beginning to think that Wednesday is the new Thursday...

I got A TAD slowed down at the very end, watching the 9/11 reading of names when I was about 90% done with the puzzle. I don't watch every year, but on a day with a sky so perfectly cloudless and blue, I can't help but be called back to that memory. So the puzzle had to be put aside! 

I'm certain to be reading too much into it, but the grid had a nicely American, dare I say NYC, feel to it today. From the jump with the delectable STELLA Parks -- do check out her recreations of classic American snacks, as well as her other great recipes -- all the way to the bottom with ANTZ being clued to Central Park. (That was a TIL for me, knowing nothing of the film!) Add in New Yorker DIANE Sawyer and the classic club sandwich, PRIDE and its NYC roots at Stonewall, Broadway musicals and American hotel chains... How about that CAN of soup adjacency with TOMATO -- hello Campbell's and Warhol! 

Almost last (in the grid) but not least, there is the Manhattan setting of Ghost and its opening scene in a dark alley in Soho, so close to the twin towers. Today of all days is one of ghosts who's memories are kept alive as a LABOR OF LOVE.
too many proper nouns killed the fun. it's impossible to solve when you shove this many proper nouns in a puzzle. really didn't enjoy today's effort.

Tough for a Wednesday, with quite a few proper names and bits of trivia I hadn‚Äôt known (characters in Ghost, the Vietnamese celebration, etc).  But once I picked up on the theme, I was off to the races. A fun one to work through!
Great puzzle!!
Unpleasant
Yes, it's been done before, and more than once, but still an enjoyable puzzle theme! Well done!

Loved this for a Wednesday. Also as we praise teachers let‚Äôs remember how much of it can, in certain classes, be about monitoring BEHAVIOR. Yes if teachers are brilliant comedians and programmatic geniuses no one misbehaves theoretically, but they get blamed if anyone does. Or if not blamed, then left to cop üëÆ e with it.

Fun puzzle from a creator I always enjoy. The theme took me a while to crack, but I laughed when I figured it out. Even then, I still took a while to solve the rest of the themed answers - added a solid 50% to my average time. Good times for a Wednesday puzzle!

Officer's breakfast?
Porridge of mess

Guess I'm tired from the sleep of lack, but I'm not coming up with any more.
Fun puzzle, Barbara.

This was fun, with just enough challenge for a Wednesday and a great theme. Thanks, Barbara Lin, and the whole team.

I've never heard "Jaws of Life", so I assume it's a US idiom. I had LIFE OF JOYS in there at first and that threw me. (Yes I have seen the film but it was a very long time ago now).

A couple of spelling pitfalls for me too. I had LOVE OF LABOUR, well I would wouldn't I, and that threw me too, and it took me a wee while to make sense of 3d.

All in all though, I enjoyed this and the theme resonated with me more than the average theme.
This was really clever and I loved it!
I loved the life of jaws clue, too!

I liked this well enough but it was kind of hard for me today. Then I had a mistake that took me 5 minutes to figure out at the end. 
The theme entries were pretty cool though!
Saved by the FUTZ.  I would never have gotten ANTZ as opposed to ANTS any other way.

I got 47D on cross clues, but it took the longest time for me to catch that the "club" referenced in the clue was a sandwich. It was one of those cases where I was so caught up in thinking of a weapon or entertainment venue or group that I couldn't make the jump to the other definition.

I quite enjoyed the puzzle, though.
Harder than the average Wednesday for me but I enjoyed it!

Yall, I have been pretty solid M-W, but the last few weeks been struggling to even finish a Monday. I feel like I‚Äôm just getting worse and worse!! Please tell me we‚Äôve entered a hard streak? Any tips for improvement?
"Study, of course" would have been a good one too. I liked this puzzle a lot. Thanks Barbara!

Today's crossword really turned me off with some incredibly obscure clues and unusually cryptic clues for a Wednesday. There were some clues that were quite straightforward so I got off to a good start but the last few clues stumped me, with "Erse" for example (obscure enough to trigger Mac's automatic red underline for a spelling error)  and "For yuks" being such an uncommon expression that when you google it you get crossword reference websites coming up before even a dictionary entry result. High dudgeon was remarked upon in Wordplay. I could go on. It took me almost as long to solve this one as Sunday's but much more frustrating.
The archaic/obscure clues and words made this one feel like solving a crossword from the archives, maybe from the 1940s. It‚Äôs one way to make things more challenging without making them more fun.

I thought this was a relatively easy puzzle, but I kept getting an error message.  I kept coming back to it all day long and finally opted for the reveal which showed an error on 35D on the letter "r" in sharps or motor.  I don't know what that means because it did not reveal anything different.
This felt refreshingly different from the usual NYT clue style. (Which I also love!) It was challenging for me without being a slog. Thanks for the fun puzzle!
Finished below my average but this felt hard for a Wednesday. High dudgeon?

OK so earlier today I saw some clever solver-concocted versions of the theme (way downstream now in Comments), & scribbled a few ideas but then had to get a lot of household things done.

These are more green-paint-y‚Äî or rather, the clues are more forced‚Äî than the nice ones I saw posted earlier, but I felt like sharing 'em anyway!


----------

1A: Stye, maybe

‚Ü™STORMOFTHEEYE‚Ü©
_____

17A: Dawn on the day of the first ever annual dreidel-spinning competition!

‚Ü™MORNINGOFTHETOP‚Ü©

_____

24A: A single-minded baseball-card collector looking to acquire only vintage cards of Brooklyn Dodgers #42

‚Ü™TRADEOFALLJACKS‚Ü©
_____

31A: "Style" columnist's biting criticism ragging on some 'ugly coifs' at the Oscars
‚Ü™DOGOFTHEHAIR‚Ü©
_____

48A: That instant when the wonderful taste of that fresh piece of chewing gum pops
‚Ü™MOMENTOFTHEFLAVOR‚Ü©
_____

57A: Supplies carried by the expedition's head Sherpa
‚Ü™PACKOFTHELEADER‚Ü©
___

67A: Anecdote about how Aesop came up with all those nuggets of wisdom that sum up his fables
‚Ü™STORYOFTHEMORAL‚Ü©
____

2D: Village in County Cork which houses the castle featuring the famous Blarney Stone
‚Ü™TOWNOFTHETALK‚Ü©
____

18D: The task of trimming a large photo of a pitcher full of Half-and Half, for a New Yorker ad that needs more room for ‚Äãcopy

‚Ü™CROPOFTHECREAM‚Ü©
___

"This bag of Fritos is so old it has some criminally stale ones! Just set the bad ones aside here, behind this yellow police tape"

‚Ü™BLOCKOFFTHEOLDCHIP‚Ü©


___

There. Now I  can move on to Thursday's puzzle!

Find a lap, gnaw on a finger, beg for another can ...? (Life of my cat).
This cat of my life is named Maggy and was adopted last April at age 15. Doing great!

Gotta say I didn't not particularly enjoy this and abandoned it before finishing, which is a rarity for me.

It insisted upon itself.

After nearly 20 years here, I have yet to find a decent bread, one that's crisp on the outside and dense on the inside, isn't sweet and is just plain delicious. Every hoagie, sub, or the like that I've had here has been on miserable soft bread. How I miss East Coast bread!

@Josh I wonder if "oh cool!" is generational, perhaps? I'm on the cusp of Gen x/Millennial and I say that alllll the time.

Sure sure, me too! I was just thrown by the generational shift. It seems like the quoted clues usually refer to language within the same argot. So, given the boomer vibe of [nifty], I was expecting something more like "groovy." Which I in fact had in my grid for waaay too long.

@Nancy 
It sounds as if you folk in NYC have not cultivated enough speeders and reckless drivers--maybe too many people using the subway or cabs or Ubers?--and therefore you have only low-quality fender-benders as a result.  For really big pile-ups and massive wrecks (often involving semis/tractor-trailers) you need more road rage and carelessness.  A really thorough crash will leave passengers and driver trapped inside the vehicle, necessitating the JAWS OF LIFE to pry the twisted metal apart before there's a fire.  (Firemen usually have this apparatus on their fire truck.)  Hope this helps.
@Manuel Pagan - Part of a club sandwich (also known in some parts as a hero or hoagie), I presume.
@Manuel Pagan - Actually I confused "club" with "sub"; different kinds of sandwich.

@Manuel Pagan A Club -sometimes Clubhouse -Sandwich is a classic staple on lunch menus. Sliced poultry (often chicken these days, but in my opinion better with turkey), bacon, lettuce, mayonnaise, and TOMATO, on toasted bread.

„Ää Giving the bird to a BLT? „Äã

@G,

I love how you found references to NYC in so many of the clues. My heart goes out today to all of those who died that day, to all of those who mourn them, and to the strength of New York.

@G 

There's also SNL! (I originally had SVU - also NYC.) 

Did club sandwiches originate in NYC? That one made me smile when I finally got it! I just had one yesterday!

Love your comment! (Well, that's not unusual but in a different way today!)

:-)

@Charles 

Again I will remind a commenter that there have always been proper nouns in puzzles, from the very first clue in the very first NYT puzzle in 1942; that puzzle and every puzzle since has had proper nouns. 

I can appreciate that you may prefer puzzles with fewer of them, but keep in mind this is just your personal preference. 

Plus, it‚Äôs not fair to say it‚Äôs impossible to solve a puzzle with many proper nouns. I and thousands of other people solved this one, and I‚Äôll bet most of us didn‚Äôt even feel that there were too many proper nouns. 

And there were very few proper nouns that might be considered obscure‚Äîmaybe OLAF, STELLA and ODA MAE. But DIANE Sawyer, EMMA Lazarus, Yoko ONO, HYATT hotels? All well known.  And all fairly crossed.
@Steve L I never heard of Diane Sawyer before, either. But, I didn't get mad about it like Charles. It gave me an opportunity to learn something new.

@Steve L 
I tend to apply the archive solvers' filter to the proper nouns; is anyone going to remember who they were in ten years? DIANE Sawyer was a gimme, but EMMA and STELLA were complete unknowns. And European political leaders are constantly changing with the winds. Liz Truss, anyone? I'm with you on the power of the crosses, though.

@Stephen I suspect that you may be in a younger generation.  None of us who were around during the Vietnam war will ever forget the Tet offensive.  I'lll add that it works both ways.  I had no idea that the title of the animated movie was spelled that way and it added a bunch of time to my solve.
@festy You suspect correctly!
As the constructor said, this is not a new theme. but it was a new take and a good puzzle nonetheless.

Strange one for me--I had the hardest time, especially in the NE, and especially for a Wednesday. With very few exceptions, though, as the puzzle filled in, I had no complaints with the cluing or the fill. EMMA Lazarus and STELLA Parks were new to me; OH COOL didn't strike me as an in-language expression of ["That's pretty nifty!"]. But a bit of new trivia and a hard clue or two doesn't usually derail me. I guess I just stayed up too late last night reveling in the punditry! No complaints at all.

Got the theme fully at ARMSOFCOAT even though I had LIFEOFJAWS, CHANGE, LABORS and PRIDE. I think I was just overthinking what the theme might be.  

The northwest was very Friday for me.  Long downs that aren't gimmies are always tough for me.  My brain has a hard time parsing the words so BEHAVIORAL came cross by cross which came inch by inch. LOL! I didn't know STELLA, didn't expect two words for OHCOOL and NONEBUT and I didn't think we'd have COITUS in a NYTimes puzzle. I also had bUTS for OUTS and eary on I had cry for SOB.
I had letter F and letter U for 54D (Mess with). I knew it *wasn't* the first word that popped into my head. :p
This has happened to me more than once and seems to be caused by a hiccup or momentary drop in my internet connection. Apparently our successes need to be instantly relayed back to the home base.

I may be wrong but I believe JAWS OF LIFE are what the fire brigade call the huge grippers that unpeel metal in car accidents. They open crushed cars like a can opener, allowing the paramedics to get to the injured, hence the name.

@David 

Don't Panic.

I feel the same way.  I don't know what it is.  No one does.

There's a lot of natural variation, and there are times when the variations tend more in one direction than another.

I see it most clearly in Wordle.  There are periods when I struggle to get down to four.  Others when a three is much more common.

@David 

I don't know if we've entered a hard streak -- I've been struggling with Sundays where I usually wouldn't, but Thursdays have seemed mild. (Acknowledging you only mentioned M-W!) But I would encourage you to keep at it! 

I like going to the archives for practice and to assuage my hurt ego: breezing through a few Mondays and/or monthly bonus puzzles helps on both counts! 

I guess another tip is, lean on the crosswordese (believe it or not!). If it seems a remote possiblity for fill, try it out -- for example, the other day there was a clue with an unusual-sounding instrument. With one crossing letter filled, I suddenly realized -- as a 4-letter answer, why not try "oboe". And I was right! 

I also like so-called proper nouns because they provide guess-proof crossings. And my personal "rules" have no qualms about looking these up when I'm stuck! 

I love devilish wordplay, but I'm not always on top of my game there. (Like today's "club"!) Wracking my brain for all possible meanings... And definitely looking away/stepping away to parse afresh really works, too. 

Good luck!!

@David 

I thought today was a bit crunchy but difficulty is so much in the beholder of the eye. 

I totally agree with Francis and G and would add that for entries that are potential word play (not obvious proper nouns, etc.), I like to say the clue over and over emphasizing different syllables and thinking through all the different definitions of a word. Often that's where I get it.

Like: Oh, *that* kind of club, for example from today. 

And sometimes I might be in a funky mood and that affects my game. 

Sometimes, when I've had a more detailed, less creative day at work (my work covers a wide range), I struggle more with wordplay unless I can get out of work-mode spreadsheet type thinking. 

Hope this helps a bit!
